Box 999, Richland, Washington 99352, United States. Graphical abstract Supported Cu, commonly containing active Cu and oxide supports, is widely used in hydrogenation of carbon-oxygen bonds. The central premise before rational improvement of Cu catalysts is to gain the fundamental insights into the relationship between catalytic performance and oxide components. Herein, ternary Cu-ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts were fabricated by a one-pot precipitation-deposition method. The Zn and Cu cations formed the rosatite mineral in solution by precipitation method and then deposited in-situ on the monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) nanoparticles. The catalyst was thus featured with well-dispersed Cu-ZnO species from mineral precursor and bifunctional sites from m-ZrO2. The trends of reaction rates normalized by the surface sites demonstrated the synergy effects of the oxide components. The catalyst gave greatly promoted reactivity (up to 92% ethylene glycol yield) and stability (over 300 h) for synthesis of ethylene glycol from dimethyl oxalate hydrogenation. The structure-performance relationship revealed that oxide components contribute to both the structural promotion and direct bifunctional effects, giving great potential for improving supported metal catalysts. Keywords Cu catalysts Strong metal-support interaction Synergy Hydrogenation 1 Introduction Cu catalyst is widely used in many reactions including hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis of carbon-oxygen bonds, methanol synthesis from carbon oxides and water-gas-shift reaction. Among the reactions, dimethyl oxalate (DMO) hydrogenation to ethylene glycol (EG) has emerged as a potential green technology routed from syngas, which can replace the traditional petroleum-based ethylene oxidation route [1]. DMO is a carboxylic di-ester that can be facilely produced from syngas while EG is a bulk chemical with an annual consumption more than 20 million tons [2]. The technology has the following features: 1) a green synthetic method via syngas from versatile starting materials (e.g., coal, methane, biomass and organic wastes); 2) usage of non-noble metal Cu catalysts; 3) the high atomic-efficiency of the process [1,3–5]. It involves the stepwise hydrogenation of two ester groups in DMO molecules. Nevertheless, severe impediments hindering the industrial application of this technology remain to be addressed. Along with high reaction rate, the occurrence of side reactions including the excessive hydrogenolysis of CO bonds and CC coupling in EG molecules need to be suppressed [6–8]. The catalyst stability due to the low Hüttig temperature (134 °C) of metallic Cu [3] and high exothermic property of DMO hydrogenation [3,9] need to be improved. Cu has the full d-orbital and relatively low activity, which usually needs to be aided by other components [10–12]. The rational improvement of Cu catalysts is the consistent pursuance of chemists. Supported Cu catalysts usually contain two indispensable parts: active Cu phases and oxide supports. The central premise is to gain the insights of the relationship between catalytic performance and catalyst components. The active Cu sites with well-dispersed and/or balanced Cu°-Cu+ states may efficiently catalyze the DMO hydrogenation [13–15]. The oxide components can not only disperse and modify Cu sites by strong metal-support interaction (SMSI), but also provide dual active centers (e.g., proper acidic sites and reducible vacancies) for facilitating the reactions [3,7,16–20]. Therefore, several factors must be taken into account before the rational improvement. (1) Cu dispersion, the dispersion need to be improved from the stage of precursor synthesis; (2) Providing dual active centers by fully utilizing the oxide supports; (3) Modulation of SMSI for maximum of synergy effects. Along with the factors, the mechanism for structural evolutions also merits to be elucidated. Recently, we have demonstrated that the mineral percursors (e.g., rosasite [(Cu,Zn)2(CO3)(OH)2] and aurichalcite [(Cu,Zn)5(OH)6(CO3)2]) can lead to highly dispersed Cu sites on the calcined catalyst which are active for hydrogenation of CO bonds [21]. ZnO derived from decomposition of the minerals possesses proper amounts of acid sites, which facilitates hydrogenation of CO bonds and has limited ability for subsequent CO hydrogenolysis [18,21]. Besides, the SMSI effect between Cu and ZnO can improve both the reactivity and stability of Cu sites [22,23]. It is well known that Zn-doped or ZnOx-modified Cu nanoparticles have superior performance for methanol synthesis from hydrogenation of carbon oxides as the results of SMSI effects [24,25]. Some oxides are capable of providing direct bifunctional centers for adsorbing and activating reactants. In this direction, we found that crystalline ZrO2 (e.g., monoclinic and tetragonal phases) can collaborate with Cu sites and contribute to hydrogenation of carbonyl groups (e.g., esters, aldehydes, ketones and acids) [3,26]. The synergistic promotion effect of ZrO2 was also observed by the groups of Lercher [27] and Bell [28] for many reactions including hydrogenation of microalgae oil and methanol synthesis, which is further convinced by the calculation works by Liu et al. [29]. It was proposed that ZrO2 is capable of adsorbing and activating CO bonds and serves as the dual sites for catalysis. Aiming at giving fundamental understanding of the roles of oxide components and providing strategies for rational improvement of catalysts, we here (1) fabricate the Cu-ZnO/ZrO2 composites based on both the mineral-dispersion strategy and the bifunctional ZrO2; (2) maximize the synergy effects by modulating the SMSI effects and catalyst compnents; (3) elucidate the structural promotion and direct synergy roles of oxides by structure-performance relationship. As illustrated in Scheme 1 , the catalyst fabrication was realized via a one-pot precipitation-deposition method. Zinc cations reacted with cupric cations by forming mineral rosasite (Eq. (S1)) in the aqueous solution [21]. Meanwhile, the mineral precursor deposited on the monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) nanoparticles, showing enhanced interaction among the components in nanometer scales. The strong interplays among the species (i.e., CuO, Cu, ZnO, and ZrO2) were observed for the as-prepared and reduced catalysts, which have great influences on the reactivity and intrinsic reactivity of catalysts. This paper not only elucidated the respective roles of oxides (structural and synergy promotions), but also showed how to utlize the oxides by modulating the SMSI effects. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and catalyst preparation The following materials have been used for the preparation of catalysts: copper nitrate trihydrate, zinc nitrate hexahydrate and sodium carbonate. All these chemicals were purchased from Sinopharm. Co. Ltd., and used without further purification. The monoclinic ZrO2 nanoparticles were purchased from Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech. Co. Ltd. The catalysts were prepared by a one-pot precipitation-deposition method. Copper nitrate and zinc nitrate with the preset contents (Cu2+/Zn2+ molar ratio of 4) were dissolved in water and mixed to form a precursor solution. The solution of Na2CO3 (2 mol/L) was used as precipitator. The monoclinic ZrO2 nanoparticles (Nanjing XFNANO Materials Tech. Co. Ltd.) were suspended in water to form the mother liquor. After that, the precursor solution and precipitator were simultaneously introduced into the mother liquor at 65 °C and a pH value of 6.5 ± 0.2. After the precipitation, the suspension was aged for 150 min, washed for 3 times and dried at 65 °C for 12 h. The resulted solid was calcined at 350 °C for 4 h in air. The resulted samples were denoted as CuZnZr-x, of which x means the molar ratio of Zr/Cu (x = 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1). 2.2 Catalyst tests Catalytic tests were performed in a fix-bed reactor with a feed of DMO in methanol solvent (15 wt. %). Prior to the tests, the catalyst was pre-loaded and in-situ reduced at 250 °C using diluted H2 atmosphere (5 vol. %) for 2 h. The products were collected in a cold trap and analyzed by a gas chromatograph equipped with a FID detector. The carbon balance of the collected products is in the range of 95%–105%. 2.3 Catalyst characterizations The element compositions were determined by the inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP, Thermo iCAP 6300). XRD experiments of the catalyst precursors and calcined catalysts were conducted on a D8 Advance Bruker diffractometer with Cu kα radiation operating at 40 kV. XRD experiments of reduced catalysts were performed on a PANalytical Empyrean instrument with Cu kα radiation after the catalysts were ex-situ reduced at 250 °C and sealed in ethanol solvent. The BET surface areas were tested via N2 physical adsorption at −196 °C using a Micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument, after the samples were degassed at 90 °C for 1 h and 350 °C for 8 h. H2 temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) and N2O titration experiments were performed on a Tianjin XQ TP-5080 instrument equipped with a TCD detector. The FT-IR spectra of the catalysts were obtained by a Nicolet NEXUS 470 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 400–4000 cm−1 with a 4 cm−1 resolution. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a Thermo XPS ESCALAB spectrometer. The XPS for the reduced catalysts were performed after the samples were in-situ reduced at 250 °C. The spectra were calibrated with the C1s peak. The surface concentrations of Cu, Zn and Zr species were estimated by the semi-quantification of XPS peaks after the peaks were calibrated based on the standard relative sensitivity factors. The Cu dispersion can be determined based on the surface concentration determined by XPS experiments and bulky concentration determined by ICP experiments. 2.4 Analytical calculations The DMO conversion (Conv.) and selectivity of products (Sel.) were calculated based on the following equations: Conv . % = 100 - Amount of DMO after reaction (mol) Total amount of DMO in the feed (mol) ×100 Sel . (%) = A product in gas or liquid phase (mol) Total amount of DMO converted (mol) ×100 For better comparison, the catalytic performance is converted to the rate of DMO and the rate of ester groups, according to the following equations: Rate of DMO mmol g cat - 1 h - 1 = Conv. (%) × W SHV ( g DMO g cat - 1 h - 1 ) × 1000 Molecule weight of DMO ( g DMO mol - 1 ) Rate of ester groups (mmol g cat - 1 h - 1 ) = Conv. (%)× ( Sel. of MG + 2 × Sel. of EG ) × W SHV ( g DMO g cat - 1 h - 1 ) × 1000 Molecule weight of DMO ( g DMO mol - 1 ) Rate normalized by surface sites was calculated by dividing the converted ester groups by the numbers of active sites at the EG yields of less than 20%. Rate normalized by surface sites = Rate of converted ester groups (mol g cat - 1 h - 1 ) Numbers of surface sites (mol g cat - 1 ) The weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) is defined as the grams of DMO per hour per gram of catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structures of catalyst precursors Retracing the preparation history to understand structural evolution of mineral precursors is powerful for preparing highly dispersed Cu catalysts. In particular, the early precipitation stage is of great importance [30]. We are aiming at integrate the mineral-derived Cu-ZnO with the synergistic ZrO2 for fabrication of the ternary Cu-ZnO/ZrO2 composites. The minerals can be produced by reacting Cu2+ and Zn2+ at different Cu2+/Zn2+ ratios using sodium carbonate as precipitator, including malachite mineral [Cu2(CO3)(OH)2], rosasite mineral [(Cu,Zn)2(CO3)(OH)2] and aurichalcite [(Cu,Zn)5(OH)6(CO3)2] [21,31]. The phase-pure rosasite with Cu/Zn molar ratio of 4 was chosen for preparing the catalysts. The m-ZrO2 nanoparticles with an average particle size of ∼28.5 nm were used as the starting material (Fig. S1, calculated by Scherrer equation). The composites were prepared by the precipitation-deposition method (Scheme 1) and denoted as CuZnZr-x, of which x means the molar ratio of Zr/Cu (x = 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1). Fig. 1 A shows the XRD patterns of the precursors of CuZnZr-x. The peaks at 17.5° (210) and 24.1° (220) can serve as the features of rosasite (PDF#36-1475). The peak at 28.2° is the characteristic of m-ZrO2 phase (PDF#37-1484). Other XRD characteristics of rosasite and m-ZrO2 in the range of 30° to 40° overlapped, which can hardly be used for differentiation of the phases. The intensity of rosasite features decreased with the elevation of Zr/Cu molar ratios, whereas that of m-ZrO2 increased and the peak width was slightly altered. The results indicated the change of relative proportions of rosasite and m-ZrO2. The m-ZrO2 is well-dispersed in the precursor and the particle sizes are almost unchangeable (Table S1). The above results revealed the successful synthesis of rosasite phase in the presence of m-ZrO2. Fig. 1B shows the IR spectra of CuZnZr-x catalyst precursors. The bands in the region of 400-700 cm−1 belong to the CuO and/or ZnO bonds in mineral structures and ZrO modes in m-ZrO2 [32]. ZrO2 showed a distinctive band at 749 cm−1 which overlapped with ν4 asymmetric OCO bending mode of rosasite [32–34]. The band intensified with the elevation of Zr/Cu ratio, indicating the increasing proportions of m-ZrO2 in the composites. The peak at 822 cm−1 is attributed to the ν2 mode of rosasite, which gradually decreased in intensity with the increase of m-ZrO2 contents [35]. The rosasite would also give arise to the bands at 1054, 1104 and 1300–1600 cm−1 which are attributed to the vibrations of CO3 2− ions. They decreased in intensity with the decrease of rosasite proportions [21,33]. Therefore, the precursors composed of Cu-Zn rosasite and m-ZrO2 have been synthesized and the presence of m-ZrO2 did not affect rosasite formation, as indicated by XRD and IR results. 3.2 Structures of calcined catalysts The ternary precursors were calcined at 350 °C to produce the CuO-ZnO/ZrO2 mixed-oxides catalysts. Table 1 summarizes the main physicochemical properties of calcined CuZnZr-x catalysts. ICP results revealed that the Cu loadings, Cu/Zn and Zr/Cu, Zn/Zr molar ratios are in consistent with the theoretical values. The addition of m-ZrO2 decreased the BET surface areas and pore volumes significantly when the Zr/Cu molar ratio is higher than 0.2. This is because of the dense property of m-ZrO2 [3]. Fig. 2 A shows the XRD patterns of the calcined CuZnZr-x catalysts. No peak related to crystalline rosasite phase was detected, indicating the total decomposition of rosasite precursors to mixed oxides. The crystalline ZnO was also not detected, indicating that the ZnO species are X-ray amorphous and/or well-dispersed within the mixed oxides. The diffraction peaks at 35.6° and 38.7° are characteristics of CuO (PDF#48-1548), whereas the peaks at 28.2° and 31.5° are assgined to monoclinic ZrO2 (PDF#37-1484). Based on the Scherrer equation, the mean sizes of CuO nanoparticles are in the range of 6–7.5 nm while the sizes of m-ZrO2 are slightly altered for the calcined CuZnZr-x catalysts (Tables 1 and S1). CuO is well dispersed due to the formation of Cu-Zn rosasite precursor (mineral-based dispersion strategy). Besides, the addition of m-ZrO2 slightly decreases the mean particle sizes of CuO. The results demonstrated the efficient dispersion strategy via formation of rosasite mineral despite of the high Cu loadings. m-ZrO2 could act as a support for rosasite and further disperse Cu species upon calcination. The IR spectra of the calcined CuZnZr-x catalysts were shown in Fig. S2. The characteristic bands in the region of 400–700 cm−1 belong to the MO bonds (M = Cu, Zn, Zr) in the oxides. The characteristic band of m-ZrO2 at 749 cm−1 gradually increased in intensity with the elevation of ZrO2 content. Most bands of the carbonate species beloning to rosasite diminished after the catalysts were calcined. The combination of IR and XRD results revealed the formation of well-despesed CuO-ZnO/ZrO2 compsites as the result of the precursor decomposition. Some residue CO3 2− species with the vibrations in the range of 1050–1100 cm−1 were also observed for the calcined catalysts [35], in particular for the CuZnZr-0.5 and CuZnZr-0.2 catalysts, which will be discussed in the following part. XPS results of the calcined CuZnZr-x catalysts revealed the strong metal-oxide interactions within the CuO-ZnO/ZrO2 compsites (Figs. 3 and S3). The Cu 2p3/2, Cu 2p1/2 peaks and accompanied satellite peaks in the range of 928–968 eV were detected. The satellite peaks in Cu 2p spectra suggested that the Cu species over calcined CuZnZr-x catalysts are +2 oxidation state [3]. With the increase of m-ZrO2 contents, the Cu 2p3/2 peaks shifted from 933.2 to 935.0 eV (Fig. 3A). Meanwhile, the binding energy of Zn 2p peaks shifted towards higher energies (∼1.2 eV), as shown in Fig. 3B. The corresponding shifts of Cu and Zn Auger lines were also observed, which confirmed the existence of strong interactions (Fig. S3). In contrast, the oppsite tendency for Zr 3d peaks was observed with the shift from 182.3 to 181.7 eV (Fig. 3C). The results revealed the strong interaction between m-ZrO2 and CuO-ZnO species. As a result, the electrons transfered from CuO and ZnO to m-ZrO2 species. Herein, the strong interactions between the CuO-ZnO and ZrO2 species were evidenced by XPS results. In view of the shifts in the binding energies, the strong interactions over the CuO-ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts are stronger than the secondary bond or Van der Waals interaction in strength. The nature of the strong interactions can be attributed to the electron transfers in the junctions or the chemical bonding interactions between CuO, ZnO and m-ZrO2 species components [36]. According to the literature reports [37,38], the work functions of Cu, Zn and Zr are 4.65, 4.33 and 4.05 respectively. The higher the work function, the more difficult the electron-emitting. The possibility of electron transfers in the heterojunctions is excluded by the trend of work functions. The chemical bonding is more possible for the stong interactions for the calcined catalysts. Along with the observation of carbonate species in IR spectra, we note that Zr 3d peaks became broader with the addition of m-ZrO2. Besides, the shoulder peak at higher binding energy emerged for CuZnZr-0.5 catalyst, which can be attributed to the existence of Zr-carbonate species. Matter et al. [39] observed that amorphous Zr-carbonate would be generated over CuO-ZnO-ZrO2 compsites derived from the coprecipitation of Cu, Zn and ZrO nitrates using Na2CO3. Sun and Sermon [40] reported that the carbonate species would serve as a type of interparticulate “chemical gluesˮ for reinforcing the interactions of the oxides. Thus, with respect to the electron transfer by the chemical bonding, the carbonate species may serve as the interfacial species. To investigate the reducibility and nature of CuO species, temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments of calcined CuZnZr-x catalysts were performed (Fig. 4 ). The broad and asymmetric reduction peaks were observed for all the catalysts, which can be attributed to the reduction of CuO species. CuZnZr-0 catalyst exhibited the main reduction peak at 208 °C and a shoulder at higher temperatures, of which the former can be attributed to the reduction of CuO particles and the latter can be assigned to the reduction of CuO species strongly interacted with ZnO components [21]. The addition of m-ZrO2 lowered the reduction temperature of CuZnZr-x catalysts. The contents of CuO species that strongly interacted with ZnO are decreased, since the shoulder peaks decreased gradually. The onset reduction temperatures for ZrO2-containing CuZnZr-x catalysts are also lower than CuZnZr-0 catalyst. This is interesting because CuO-ZnO species are strongly interacted with m-ZrO2. Rodriguez et al. suggested that reduction of CuO is started from the nucleation of adsorption sites for H2 dissociation and accompanied with an induction period [41,42]. The promotion of CuO reduction is related to the promoted populations of sites for H2 activation and the surface for H2 reduction. According to the XRD and XPS results, the addition of m-ZrO2 not only slightly decreased the particle sizes of CuO, but also helped the creation of sites for H2 dissociation [7,43]. The reduction of CuO is therefore promoted due to the higher surface area exposed to H2 and sites for H2 activation, which are in accordance with the literature reports [44,45]. Thus, the decrease of reduction temperature can be the indicator for both the structural promotion and strong interaction of m-ZrO2 for Cu catalysts. 3.3 Structures of reduced catalysts The CuZnZr-x catalysts were reduced at 250 °C by H2. The satellite peaks of Cu 2p disappeared while the 2p peaks became sharper and shifted to the lower binding energy (∼931.8 and ∼951.7 eV), indicating the reduction of Cu2+ species to those with lower valence states (Fig. 5 A). It is reported that the presence of oxides that strongly interacted with CuO would delay the reduction of Cu2+ species and result in the formation of both Cu° and Cu+ species [41,42]. To better differentiate the valence states of Cu species, we collected the Cu LMM Auger spectra for the reduced catalysts since the gap between kinetic energies of Cu° and Cu+ is as large as 2–4 eV [46]. As shown in Fig. 5B, the reduced catalysts all exhibited typical Auger lines for metallic Cu° state which centered at ∼918 eV [46]. The evidence of positive charged Cu+ species was not observed over the reduced surfaces. The absence of Cu+ species is mainly because of the kinetic effects during the reductive activation processes, although the thermodynamics is favored for the formation of Cu+ intermediate [41]. This is confirmed by TPR results that the catalysts are reduced before 250 °C and in consistent with the recent experimental reports in promoted Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZrO2 catalysts [47,48]. Fig. 5C shows the XRD results of reduced CuZnZr-x catalysts. The diffractions belonging to Cu, m-ZrO2 and slight ZnO crystalline were observed. No peaks related to CuO and Cu2O were detected, supporting the XPS results. The crystalline sizes of Cu, m-ZrO2 and ZnO species over the reduced CuZnZr-x catalysts were calculated by Scherrer equation (Tables 1 and S1). The mean diameters of Cu nanoparticles over reduced CuZnZr-x catalysts are in the range of 16.6–19.2 nm and those of ZnO species are in the range of 8–9.3 nm. The influence of size effects of Cu species is minimized for analyzing the roles of oxide supports. Interestingly, the particle sizes of m-ZrO2 species increased into 38.3–46.9 nm after the catalysts were reduced. In all, highly dispersed Cu species were obtained by formation of mineral precursor with Zn2+ species and structural promotion of m-ZrO2 via the one-pot precipitation-deposition method. The ZrO2 contents modulated the surface states and concentrations of Cu-ZnO species and ZrO2 sites, which would be a potential model for settling the roles of oxide components. 3.4 Structural evolutions during the calcination and reduction XPS is a surface-sensitive technique for catalyst characterizations. Previous reports have suggested that the XPS intensities are correlated well with the metal dispersions [49,50]. For determining Cu surface area, Fichtl et al. reported that the accuracy of common N2O titration method is dramatically influenced by the oxides (e.g., ZnO) [51]. Therefore, we employed the quantitative analysis of XPS for determining the concentrations of surface species (e.g., CuO, Cu, ZnO and ZrO2) [49,50]. The concentrations of surface species are different from the bulk values determined by ICP experiments (Fig. 6 ). Along with the strong interactions, the surface species were evolved and the surface concentrations were modulated during the calcination and reduction processes. 1 Enrichments of ZnO over CuO and Cu surfaces were observed Fig. 6A shows the relationship between surface Cu/Zn molar ratios and ZrO2 contents for the calcined and reduced catalysts. They were measured by semi-quantitative analysis of XPS results. The bulk Cu/Zn ratios determined by ICP experiments were taken as the reference. Cu/Zn molar ratios decreased from ∼4 to ∼2 for all the calcined samples, revealing that the strong interaction of CuO and ZnO resulted in the enrichment of ZnO species over CuO. The Cu/Zn ratios decreased into ∼1 upon further reduction of the catalysts, indicating that ZnO species were enriched on the Cu nanoparticles over reduced catalysts. This is in consistent with the long-established concept “SMSI” proposed by Tauster et al. [52,53]. The results indicated the formation of active Cu-ZnOx synergy sites featured with Cu/Zn ratio of ∼1. The surface ZnOx species can be either surface alloy or oxide overlayer structures [24,54]. Considering the observations in TPR and XRD experiments, it is believed that the surface ZnOx species are oxide overlayer structures. 2 Enrichment of ZnO over ZrO2 surface was observed Fig. 6B shows the surface Zn/Zr molar ratios and the bulk values. The Zn/Zr molar ratios of the calcined catalysts were greatly higher than the bulk values while they were further boosted when the catalysts were reduced. The observations revealed the enrichment of ZnO species over ZrO2 surface and explained the strong interactions between ZnO and ZrO2 observed in XPS analysis. The trend is similar to the enrichment of ZnO over CuO/Cu surfaces. 3 CuO is enriched over ZrO2 surface for the calcined catalysts while Cu isolated from ZrO2 after reduction For the calcined CuZnZr-x catalysts, the Cu/Zr molar ratios are greatly higher than the bulk molar ratios (Fig. 6C). In contrast to the results of Cu/Zn and Zn/Zr molar ratios, the Cu/Zr molar ratios of reduced catalysts are close to the actual values determined by ICP experiments. The results indicated the isolation of Cu nanoparticles from ZrO2 surface. By means of the XRD, TPR and semi-quantitative analysis of XPS results, the general pictures on the structural evolutions of both the calcined CuO-ZnO/ZrO2 and reduced Cu-ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts emerged (Fig. 6D). Along with the structural evolutions, the concentrations of surface species were shown in Tables 1 and S2. The addition of ZrO2 can promote the dispersion of Cu species. The results demonstrated that the catalyst nanostructures and the metal-oxide interactions of the ternary catalysts can be tailored by in-situ depositing the Cu-Zn mineral precursors on ZrO2 nanoparticles. The distributions of surface species would have great influences on the catalytic performance, since the ZnO and ZrO2 are considered as the synergistic components for hydrogenation of carbonoxygen bonds. 3.5 Catalytic performance of catalysts The CuZnZr-x catalysts were employed for DMO hydrogenation to EG at low temperature (190 °C) (Fig. 7 ). At the conditions, the DMO conversions and EG yields are relatively low, which are beneficial for better differentiation of the catalyst reactivity. The consumption rate of DMO molecules (converted DMO per gram catalyst per hour) and the rate of ester groups (converted ester groups per gram catalyst per hour) varied with the CuZnZr-x catalysts. A volcano trend with the increase of ZrO2 content is observed for both the DMO rate and the ester rate. Compared with CuZnZr-0, CuZnZr-x (x = 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1) catalysts showed an improved activity, indicating the synergy effect of m-ZrO2 for hydrogenation of CO bonds, which is in accordance with our previous observations in Cu/ZrO2/SiO2 catalysts [3]. The addition of ZrO2 can promote the adsorption and activation of CO bonds, as well as conversion of O-containing intermediates into methyl glycolate (MG) and EG [27,48]. Among the CuZnZr-x catalysts, CuZnZr-0.2 showed the best activity due to the fact that the surface Cu concentration decreased with the increase of ZrO2 component. The rates for DMO hydrogenation for the CuZnZr-x catalysts were measured at EG yield lower than 20%. Since Cu and ZrO2 have been proved to be the dual site for hydrogenation of carbonyl groups, the reaction rates were normalized by both the surface metallic Cu sites and ZrO2 sites (RateCu and Rate ZrO 2 repsectively) (Fig. 8 ) [48]. The reaction rates normalized by surface ZnO (RateZnO) were also calculated as the reference to demonstrate the Cu-ZnO synergy [54]. The absolute values of normalized rates are meaningless while the trends and differences of apparent values are meaningful for analyzing the synergy effects [55]. The RateCu gradually increased with the addition of m-ZrO2 when the Zr/Cu molar ratio is lower than 0.2 (ZrO2 content of 19.5 wt. %). Thereafter, the RateCu reached a platform and was not promoted by the further addition of m-ZrO2. The RateZnO based on the surface ZnO species followed the similar trends to RateCu. In contrast, the Rate ZrO 2 decreased with the increase of ZrO2 contents. It decreased rapidly when the ZrO2 content is higher than 19.5 wt. %. The above results suggested that the optimization of Cu catalysts lies on both the direct synergy promotion (Rigion I in Fig. 8) and structural promotion effects (Rigion II in Fig. 8). When the ZrO2 content is lower than 19.5 wt. % (Zr/Cu molar ratio of 0.2), m-ZrO2 mainly acted as a dual synergy sites for adsorption and activation of CO bonds [27,48], which promoted the intrinsic reactivity of Cu sites. When the ZrO2 content is further increased, the excessive m-ZrO2 would provide a structural promotion effects for Cu catalysts, since the intrinsic reactivity of Cu sites is slightly altered. However, it should be noted that ZrO2 is a relatively awkward support for structural promotion of Cu catalysts in our cases, in compared with the high surface area supports. This is supported by the trend of BET surface area that it decreased gradually with the addition of ZrO2. Further optimizations of the oxides supported Cu catalysts based on the dual promotion effects are needed. For optimization of EG yield, the effect of reaction temperature for CuZnZr-0.2 catalyst was investigated (Fig. 9 A). At 190 °C, 59.2% of DMO was converted. The MG and EG selectivity reaches 66.4% and 31.9% respectively. Increase of the reaction temperature increased both the DMO conversion and EG selectivity while decreased MG selectivity. The optimized EG selectivity (92%) is achieved at 220 °C with a full conversion of DMO. Upon further elevating the reaction temperature, EG selectivity decreased whereas some ethanol and 1,2-butanediol (1,2-BDO) were produced. The results indicated the high reaction temperatures promoted the over-hydrogenolysis and CC coupling reactions by [6,18]. The step-wise hydrogenation pathway of DMO to EG, passing through MG intermediate was revealed (Fig. 9B). Stability of Cu catalysts is a long-term concern for industrial applications of DMO hydrogenation, since the Hüttig temperature of metallic Cu is as low as 134 °C [56]. It is widely considered that working above the Hüttig temperature would cause the gradual deactivation due to Cu sintering. Modulation of the metal-support interaction (e.g., Cu-ZnO and Cu-ZrO2) and full utilization of synergistic roles of ZrO2 are effective compensation for enhancement of catalyst stability [3,23]. The stability of CuZnZr-0.2 was therefore tested under the optimized conditions. As shown in Fig. 9C, a stable performance was observed during the 300 h tests. DMO conversion maintained at above 95% and the EG yield varied in the range of 90–95%. The superior stability can be attributed to the combination of the bifunctional effects of ZrO2 for reactant activation and structural promotion by strong metal-support interactions. The bifunctional and structural promotion effects are modulated by the simple mineral-based dispersion strategy and deposition-precipitation method. 4 Conclusion The Cu-ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts were constructed by combination of Cu-Zn rosasite and monoclinic ZrO2 nanoparticles using a one-pot precipitation-deposition method. The characterization results showed that dispersion of Cu species was facilitated by both formation of rosasite phases and addition of monoclinic ZrO2 nanoparticles. The strong metal-oxide interactions were observed among CuO, ZnO and ZrO2 species over the calcined catalysts, which were further evolved upon reduction of the catalysts. The strong interactions tailored the surface nanostructures of the reduced catalysts and enabled the synergistic effects of ZrO2, leading to the promoted catalytic performance for DMO hydrogenation to EG. The Cu-ZnO/ZrO2 catalyst with a Zr/Cu ratio of 0.2 gave a high EG yield of 92% and stable performance at optimized conditions. By comparison of the intrinsic reactivity, the direct synergistic bifunctional roles and the structural promotion of ZrO2 were demonstrated. The results here are anticipated to guide the further improvement of supported Cu catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Supported Cu, commonly containing active Cu and oxide supports, is widely used in hydrogenation of carbon-oxygen bonds. The central premise before rational improvement of Cu catalysts is to gain the fundamental insights into the relationship between catalytic performance and oxide components. Herein, ternary Cu-ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts were fabricated by a one-pot precipitation-deposition method. The Zn and Cu cations formed the rosatite mineral in solution by precipitation method and then deposited in-situ on the monoclinic ZrO2 (m-ZrO2) nanoparticles. The catalyst was thus featured with well-dispersed Cu-ZnO species from mineral precursor and bifunctional sites from m-ZrO2. The trends of reaction rates normalized by the surface sites demonstrated the synergy effects of the oxide components. The catalyst gave greatly promoted reactivity (up to 92% ethylene glycol yield) and stability (over 300 h) for synthesis of ethylene glycol from dimethyl oxalate hydrogenation. The structure-performance relationship revealed that oxide components contribute to both the structural promotion and direct bifunctional effects, giving great potential for improving supported metal catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Strong metal-oxide interactions induce bifunctional and structural effects for Cu catalysts
